post_text: Congratulations!
shared_text:
Oak Hills High School
June 2 at 1:03 PM ·

Congratulations to OHHS freshman Allison Rodriquez, whose exhibit “We Can Do It: Women in World War II” advanced to the final round of competition in California’s National History Day - a national research-based project contest. This places her work among the top 15 individual exhibits in the state!

Joining Allison at the “virtual” state competition were senior Karen Palma Garcia with her exhibit “Innovation on the Battlefield of the Civil War,” and senior Angel Moreno Rosales with his documentary “We the People: 229 Years Later” (https://youtu.be/ZiiLPaVGBu0 ). They represented Oak Hills HS and San Bernardino County among over 1,700 students from all over California in the “virtual” National History Day contest.

Congratulations to Oak Hills team "Dogbyte" for representing HUSD in a nationwide competition called picoCTF. The team placed 197 out of 5,151 active teams. Team "Dogbyte" placed in the top 3.8% of the entire nation.

picoCTF is a free computer security game targeted at middle and high school students, created by security experts at Carnegie Mellon University. The game consists of a series of challenges centered around a unique storyline where participants must reverse engineer, break, hack, decrypt, or do whatever it takes to solve the challenge. The challenges are all set up with the intent of being hacked, making it an excellent, legal way to get hands-on experience. Congratulations to team members Diego Briceno Estrada, Tyler Behrends, Connery Ryan, and Sky Hernandez
Job well done!
